meanings.definition: To value or estimate too highly.
meanings.sent1: Some people tend to overprize expensive items, thinking they are better than they really are.
meanings.sent2: She always overprizes her own abilities, which sometimes leads to disappointment.
meanings.sent3: The little girl overprized her drawing so much that she believed it could come to life.
meanings.sent4: He tends to overprize his collection of old coins, seeing them as priceless treasures.
meanings.sent5: The coach warned the team not to overprize the upcoming match, as every opponent is tough.

meanings.definition: To set too high a price on.
meanings.sent1: The seller tends to overprize his products, making them unaffordable for many customers.
meanings.sent2: It's important not to overprize your services, as you may lose potential clients.
meanings.sent3: The artist accidentally overprized his artwork, scaring away potential buyers.
meanings.sent4: She realized she had overprized the antique vase when no one was willing to buy it.
meanings.sent5: The shopkeeper decided to overprize the limited edition items to attract collectors.

meanings.sent1: He tends to overprize his achievements, often boasting about them to everyone.
meanings.sent2: She would overprize her favorite possessions, considering them more valuable than anything else.
meanings.sent3: The child overprized the toy he won at the fair, carrying it everywhere with him.
meanings.sent4: The actor overprized his award, displaying it prominently in his living room.
meanings.sent5: The teacher warned the students not to overprize perfect scores, as learning is more important than grades.
